questions.question: Section 1231 property includes:

options.B: Depreciable property and real property used in a trade or business held more than one year

questions.explanation: Section 1231 property includes depreciable property and land used in a trade or business, held for more than one year. This is NOT a capital asset by definition, but Section 1231 provides potential capital gain treatment on net gains.
questions.tip: Section 1231 = business property held >1 year. Gets best-of-both-worlds treatment.

questions.question: The benefit of Section 1231 is that net gains are treated as:

options.B: Long-term capital gain, while net losses are ordinary

questions.explanation: Section 1231 provides 'best of both worlds' treatment: net Section 1231 gains are treated as long-term capital gains (preferential rates), while net Section 1231 losses are treated as ordinary losses (fully deductible against ordinary income).
questions.tip: 1231 net gain = LTCG rate. 1231 net loss = ordinary deduction. Win-win.

questions.question: Section 1245 property includes:

options.B: Personal property used in business (machinery, equipment, vehicles)

questions.explanation: Section 1245 property includes depreciable personal property used in a trade or business, such as machinery, equipment, furniture, and vehicles. It also includes certain amortizable intangibles and some real property like single-purpose agricultural structures.
questions.tip: Section 1245 = depreciable personal property (equipment, machinery, vehicles).

questions.question: Section 1250 property refers to:

options.B: Depreciable real property (buildings)

questions.explanation: Section 1250 property is depreciable real property—primarily buildings and structural components. This includes commercial buildings, residential rental property, and other improvements to real property (but not land, which isn't depreciable).
questions.tip: Section 1250 = depreciable real property (buildings). Not land.

questions.question: Depreciation recapture rules exist to:

options.A: Increase the taxpayer's basis in property
options.B: Prevent taxpayers from taking ordinary deductions and later receiving capital gain treatment on the same amount
options.D: Convert capital gains to ordinary income permanently

questions.explanation: Depreciation recapture prevents taxpayers from getting the best of both worlds: ordinary deductions during the holding period and then capital gain rates on sale. The recaptured depreciation is taxed as ordinary income.
questions.tip: Recapture = you got ordinary deduction, so you pay ordinary tax on that portion.

questions.question: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain on real property is taxed at a maximum rate of:
questions.explanation: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain (straight-line depreciation on real property) is taxed at a maximum rate of 25%. This is higher than regular capital gains rates but lower than ordinary income rates.
questions.tip: Unrecaptured 1250 = 25% max. It's the 'in-between' rate for real estate depreciation.

questions.question: Section 1245 recapture is the lesser of:

options.B: Gain realized or fair market value
options.D: Fair market value or original cost

questions.explanation: Section 1245 recapture is the lesser of: (1) gain realized (amount realized minus adjusted basis), or (2) depreciation taken (sometimes called 'recomputed basis minus adjusted basis'). You can't recapture more depreciation than your actual gain.
questions.tip: 1245 recapture = lesser of gain or depreciation taken. Taxed as ordinary income.

questions.question: Section 1245 recapture for personal property generally equals:

options.B: ALL depreciation taken, up to the amount of gain

questions.explanation: For Section 1245 property (personal property), ALL depreciation taken is potentially recaptured as ordinary income, limited by the gain recognized. This is 'full recapture' unlike Section 1250's limited recapture.
questions.tip: 1245 = full recapture (all depreciation). 1250 = limited recapture (excess only, usually).

questions.question: For real property placed in service after 1986, Section 1250 recapture applies to:

options.B: Depreciation in excess of straight-line (usually zero)

questions.explanation: Section 1250 requires ordinary income recapture only for depreciation in excess of straight-line. Since MACRS uses straight-line for real property (post-1986), there's typically no 1250 recapture—but there is 'unrecaptured 1250 gain' at 25%.
questions.tip: Post-1986 real estate: no actual 1250 recapture (all straight-line), but 25% unrecaptured gain.

questions.question: When property is sold at a gain, depreciation recapture is recognized:

options.B: Before Section 1231 gain determination
options.C: Only if elected by the taxpayer

questions.explanation: Recapture is determined first, reducing the gain that goes into the Section 1231 netting process. Only the gain remaining after recapture is treated as Section 1231 gain. The ordering is: recapture → Section 1231 → capital gain netting.
questions.tip: First recapture, then 1231 netting. Recapture pulls gain out of favorable treatment.

questions.question: The Section 1231 lookback rule requires:

options.A: Gain to be recognized over 5 years
options.B: Current year net 1231 gain to be treated as ordinary income to extent of prior 5-year net 1231 losses
options.C: Losses to be carried back 2 years
options.D: All gains to be ordinary income

questions.explanation: The lookback rule prevents taxpayers from recognizing ordinary losses in one year and capital gains in another on Section 1231 property. Net 1231 gains are recharacterized as ordinary income to the extent of unrecaptured net 1231 losses from the prior 5 years.
questions.tip: Lookback: prior 5 years' 1231 losses convert current 1231 gains to ordinary.

questions.question: Equipment with original cost of $50,000 and accumulated depreciation of $30,000 is sold for $45,000. The Section 1245 recapture is:
questions.explanation: Adjusted basis = $50,000 - $30,000 = $20,000. Gain = $45,000 - $20,000 = $25,000. Recapture = lesser of gain ($25,000) or depreciation ($30,000) = $25,000. All gain is recaptured as ordinary income.
questions.tip: Recapture = lesser of gain or depreciation. Here: $25K gain < $30K depreciation.

questions.conceptTested: Sale at a loss and recapture
questions.question: If depreciable property is sold at a loss:

options.B: There is no depreciation recapture
options.D: The loss is converted to ordinary income

questions.explanation: Depreciation recapture only applies when there is a gain. If property is sold at a loss (amount realized less than adjusted basis), there is no recapture. The loss is a Section 1231 loss and may be ordinary if net 1231 is a loss.
questions.tip: No gain = no recapture. Recapture only applies to the extent of gain.

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange, depreciation recapture is:

options.B: Recognized only to the extent of boot received
options.D: Recognized in full regardless of boot

questions.explanation: In a like-kind exchange, recapture is recognized to the extent of boot received (lesser of boot or recapture potential). If no boot is received, recapture is deferred. The recapture potential carries over to the replacement property.
questions.tip: 1031 with boot: recapture recognized first, before other gain.

questions.question: When depreciable property is given as a gift:

options.B: Recapture potential transfers to the donee
options.D: The donor must pay recapture tax

questions.explanation: A gift is not a recognition event for depreciation recapture. The recapture potential carries over to the donee along with the carryover basis. The donee will recognize recapture when they sell the property.
questions.tip: Gift = no recapture trigger. Recapture potential follows the property.

questions.question: When depreciable property is inherited:

options.B: Recapture potential is eliminated due to stepped-up basis
options.C: Recapture is deferred until the heir sells

questions.explanation: Inherited property receives a stepped-up basis to FMV at death, eliminating the built-in depreciation recapture. This is a significant benefit—the decedent's depreciation deductions never result in recapture at ordinary rates.
questions.tip: Death step-up eliminates recapture potential. Major estate planning benefit.

questions.question: In an installment sale of Section 1245 property, depreciation recapture is:

options.A: Recognized ratably as payments are received
options.B: Recognized in full in the year of sale
options.D: Recognized in the final year of payments

questions.explanation: Depreciation recapture cannot be deferred using the installment method. All recapture income is recognized in the year of sale, even if payment is received over time. Only the gain exceeding recapture can be reported on the installment method.
questions.tip: Recapture = immediate recognition. No installment deferral for recapture portion.

questions.question: When Section 1245 property is donated to charity:

options.A: The charitable deduction is reduced by the recapture amount
options.B: Recapture is recognized as ordinary income

questions.explanation: When donating ordinary income property (including the recapture portion of Section 1245 property), the charitable deduction is limited to basis, not FMV. The recapture reduces the deduction rather than creating taxable income.
questions.tip: Donate 1245 property = deduction limited to basis. Recapture 'built in' reduces deduction.

questions.question: In the Section 1231 netting process, first you net:

options.B: Casualty gains and losses in the 'hotchpot,' then combine with other 1231 gains/losses

questions.explanation: The 1231 process involves: (1) net casualty and theft gains/losses (if net loss, treat as ordinary; if net gain, move to main pot), (2) net the main 1231 gains and losses (including casualty net gain), (3) apply lookback rule, (4) characterize the result.
questions.tip: Two-step 1231: first casualties (hotchpot), then combine with other 1231 transactions.

questions.question: For corporations, Section 291 requires additional recapture of:

options.B: 20% of the difference between 1245 recapture and 1250 recapture for real property

questions.explanation: Section 291 requires corporations to recapture an additional 20% of the excess of what would be 1245 recapture over actual 1250 recapture on real property. This effectively recaptures 20% of straight-line depreciation on buildings.
questions.tip: Corps pay extra: 20% of (1245 recapture - 1250 recapture) on real property.

questions.question: Section 179 expense is subject to recapture when:

options.B: The property's business use drops to 50% or below before the end of the MACRS recovery period
options.C: The property is sold at any time

questions.explanation: If business use of Section 179 property drops to 50% or less before the end of the MACRS recovery period, the excess Section 179 deduction over regular MACRS depreciation must be recaptured as ordinary income.
questions.tip: 179 recapture: business use drops ≤50%. Recapture = 179 taken - what MACRS would have been.

questions.question: When a building is sold along with personal property inside it:

options.B: The sale must be allocated, with personal property subject to 1245 and building subject to 1250

questions.explanation: When selling property that includes both real property (building) and personal property (equipment, fixtures), the total price must be allocated based on fair market values. Each type follows its own recapture rules.
questions.tip: Allocate between 1245 personal property and 1250 real property by FMV.

questions.question: Equipment cost $100,000, depreciation taken $80,000, sold for $90,000. The Section 1231 gain is:
questions.explanation: Adjusted basis = $100,000 - $80,000 = $20,000. Gain = $90,000 - $20,000 = $70,000. Section 1245 recapture = lesser of gain ($70,000) or depreciation ($80,000) = $70,000 ordinary. Remaining 1231 gain = $0.
questions.tip: All $70K gain is 1245 recapture (ordinary). No 1231 gain remains.

questions.question: A building cost $500,000, depreciation taken $100,000, sold for $600,000. The unrecaptured Section 1250 gain taxed at 25% is:
questions.explanation: Adjusted basis = $500,000 - $100,000 = $400,000. Total gain = $600,000 - $400,000 = $200,000. Unrecaptured 1250 gain = lesser of gain ($200,000) or depreciation ($100,000) = $100,000 at 25%. Remaining $100,000 is Section 1231 gain.
questions.tip: Unrecaptured 1250 = depreciation recaptured at 25% (lesser of gain or depreciation).

questions.question: Bonus depreciation under Section 168(k) is subject to:

options.A: Special recapture rules separate from Section 1245
options.B: Full Section 1245 recapture as ordinary income like regular depreciation

questions.explanation: Bonus depreciation is treated like other MACRS depreciation for recapture purposes. It is included in total depreciation subject to Section 1245 recapture and is recaptured as ordinary income to the extent of gain on sale.
questions.tip: Bonus depreciation = part of 1245 recapture. No special treatment.

questions.question: Equipment cost $60,000, depreciation taken $45,000, sold for $75,000. The character of the $60,000 gain is:
questions.explanation: Adjusted basis = $60,000 - $45,000 = $15,000. Gain = $75,000 - $15,000 = $60,000. Section 1245 recapture = lesser of gain ($60,000) or depreciation ($45,000) = $45,000 ordinary. Remaining $15,000 is Section 1231 gain.
questions.tip: Split: $45K 1245 recapture (ordinary) + $15K excess = 1231 gain.

questions.question: Qualified improvement property (interior improvements to nonresidential buildings) is treated for recapture purposes as:

options.B: Section 1245 property

questions.explanation: Qualified improvement property, despite being real property, is often treated as Section 1245 property for recapture purposes due to special depreciation rules. This subjects it to full recapture rather than the limited 1250 recapture.
questions.tip: QIP can be 1245 property despite being building improvements. Full recapture possible.

questions.question: Gain from the sale of land used for farming that has had soil and water conservation expenses deducted is subject to:

options.B: Ordinary income recapture under Section 1252

questions.explanation: Section 1252 requires recapture as ordinary income of previously deducted soil and water conservation expenses when farm land is sold within 10 years. The recapture phases out: 100% if sold within 5 years, decreasing 20% per year thereafter.
questions.tip: Farm land conservation expenses: recaptured if sold within 10 years (Section 1252).

questions.question: Gain from the sale of amortizable Section 197 intangibles is subject to:

options.B: Section 1245 recapture (full recapture)

questions.explanation: Section 197 intangibles (goodwill, covenants not to compete, customer lists, etc.) are subject to Section 1245 recapture. All amortization previously deducted is recaptured as ordinary income to the extent of gain.
questions.tip: 197 intangibles = 1245 property. Full recapture of amortization.

questions.question: When 1245 property is sold to a related party at a loss, any gain on subsequent sale by the related party is:

options.B: Ordinary income to extent of depreciation taken by the original owner

questions.explanation: When Section 1245 property is transferred to a related party (in a transaction where loss is disallowed), the recapture taint follows the property. Any gain on subsequent sale by the related party is ordinary income to the extent of the original owner's depreciation.
questions.tip: Related party sale: recapture taint transfers. Later gain = ordinary to extent of prior depreciation.

questions.question: When the Section 1231 netting produces a net loss, the loss is treated as:

options.B: Short-term capital loss
options.C: Ordinary loss fully deductible against ordinary income
options.D: Suspended until a net 1231 gain year

questions.explanation: Net Section 1231 losses are treated as ordinary losses, fully deductible against ordinary income without the $3,000 capital loss limitation. This is the 'loss' benefit of Section 1231's best-of-both-worlds treatment.
questions.tip: Net 1231 loss = ordinary loss (fully deductible). Better than capital loss.

questions.question: Building cost $1,000,000, depreciation $200,000, sold for $1,500,000. How much is taxed at each rate?

options.B: $200,000 at 25% (unrecaptured 1250), $500,000 at LTCG rates

questions.explanation: Adjusted basis = $800,000. Gain = $700,000. Unrecaptured 1250 = $200,000 (depreciation) at 25%. Remaining $500,000 = 1231 gain → LTCG rates. No actual 1250 recapture (ordinary) because straight-line was used.
questions.tip: Building gain: depreciation portion at 25%, excess at LTCG rates.

questions.question: When a partnership sells Section 1245 property, the recapture:

options.A: Is recognized at the partnership level only
options.B: Passes through to partners and is ordinary income to each partner
options.D: Is recognized only by the general partner

questions.explanation: When a partnership sells Section 1245 property, the recapture income passes through to partners. Each partner reports their share of the ordinary income from recapture on their individual return, maintaining the character.
questions.tip: Partnership 1245 recapture: passes through as ordinary income to partners.

questions.question: Under Section 1239, gain on the sale of depreciable property between related parties is treated as:

options.B: Ordinary income regardless of recapture rules
options.D: Deferred until property is sold outside the group

questions.explanation: Section 1239 converts all gain to ordinary income (not just recapture) when depreciable property is sold between related parties. This prevents sellers from converting ordinary income to capital gain through related party sales.
questions.tip: Section 1239: sell depreciable property to related party = ALL gain is ordinary.

questions.question: When business property is destroyed in a casualty and insurance proceeds exceed basis:

options.B: Section 1245 or 1250 recapture applies to the gain, same as a sale
options.D: Only the excess is subject to recapture

questions.explanation: Casualty gains on business property are subject to the same recapture rules as sales. The gain (insurance proceeds minus adjusted basis) triggers 1245 or 1250 recapture to the extent of depreciation. The involuntary conversion rules may allow deferral.
questions.tip: Casualty gain = recapture applies. Can defer under Section 1033 if reinvest.
